metadata.unitName: TEST orange Using Materials for a Purpose

questions.question: Which of the following is a natural material?

answers.explanation: Plastic is manufactured from petro-chemicals, so it is a processed material.
Wool comes directly from sheep, so it is a natural material.
Glass is made by humans by heating sand and other additives, so it is processed.
Concrete is a human-made composite material.

questions.question: Which pair of words are antonyms when describing material properties?

answers.explanation: Rigid and flexible are opposites.
Smooth describes texture, hard describes resistance – they are not opposites.
A material can be both waterproof and transparent (e.g. glass), so they are not opposites.
Strength and mass are different concepts, not opposites.

questions.question: Which two properties best describe ordinary window glass?

answers.explanation: Light passes through glass (transparent) and it does not let water soak in (waterproof).
Glass is see-through and usually smooth.
Glass neither soaks up water nor bends easily.
Compared to many materials, glass is relatively heavy and hard.

questions.question: Explain TWO properties that make wood a suitable material for building a treehouse.

answers.content: Any two of: lightweight / relatively light; strong under compression and tension; renewable / sustainable; can be cut and joined easily; provides good insulation; is rigid.
answers.explanation: Wood’s combination of strength and light mass allows a tree to support it; it is also easy to shape and fix, making construction practical.

questions.question: Which item below is made from a processed material?

answers.explanation: Granite is a natural rock (only cut and polished).
Aluminium metal is extracted from bauxite ore by industrial processing.
Shells are natural materials gathered from animals.
The fibre is natural, only spun and knitted.

questions.question: During the Materials Soundscape activity, students used their senses to identify materials. Name TWO senses they used and briefly describe how each sense helped.

answers.content: Hearing – students listened to the sound each material made (e.g. clink of glass) to identify it; Touch – when handling real samples they felt texture/temperature/rigidity to decide which material matched the clue.

questions.question: Draw a two-column chart. Label one column ‘Natural’ and the other ‘Processed’. Place at least FOUR everyday materials (two in each column) in the correct place.

answers.content: Teacher to sight student work for two correct examples in each column.

questions.question: In Activity 7, how did students test whether a material was waterproof?

answers.explanation: This tests hardness, not waterproofness.
This would not show waterproofness.

answers.content: Drop water onto it with a pipette and observe whether the water is absorbed
answers.explanation: If the water beads and runs off, the material is waterproof; if it soaks in, it is absorbent.

answers.content: Weigh it before and after wiping it
answers.explanation: Weight change alone was not part of the lesson procedure.

questions.question: Gold is prized for jewellery mainly because it is:

answers.explanation: Gold is dense and usually polished smooth.
Gold can be hammered into shapes (malleable) and has a bright lustre (shiny).
Gold neither soaks up liquids nor bends like fabric.
Gold is opaque and relatively soft.

questions.question: Write TWO pairs of opposite (antonym) properties used to describe materials.

answers.content: Any two correct pairs, e.g. waterproof/absorbent; dull/shiny; strong/weak; transparent/opaque; flexible/rigid; light/heavy; rough/smooth; hard/soft.
answers.explanation: Accept any valid antonym pair discussed in the lesson.

questions.question: Which property makes rubber a suitable material for making gumboots?

answers.explanation: Transparency is not needed for gumboots.
Rubber keeps water out while allowing comfortable movement.
Electrical conductivity is irrelevant here.
A brittle material would crack and leak.

questions.question: Why is glass commonly used for window panes?

answers.explanation: Glass is not magnetic.

answers.content: It is transparent and lets light through
answers.explanation: Transparency allows light into buildings while still providing a barrier.

answers.content: It is a good electrical conductor
answers.explanation: Electrical conductivity is not required for windows.
Glass does not rust.

questions.question: What do we call giving an old product a new purpose instead of throwing it away?

answers.explanation: Repurposing means using an object for a different function than it was originally designed for.

questions.question: Concrete is an example of a composite material. What is a composite material?

answers.content: A material found only in nature
answers.explanation: Composites can be natural or man-made.

answers.content: A single pure substance with no additives
answers.explanation: Composites are made from more than one substance.

answers.content: A material made by combining two or more materials with different properties
answers.explanation: The combination gives the new material useful, unique properties.

answers.content: Any material that melts when heated
answers.explanation: Melting point does not define a composite.

questions.question: Which of the following is a natural material?

answers.explanation: Plastic is processed from petroleum.
Steel is processed from iron ore.
Wool is obtained directly from sheep and is natural.
Fibreglass is a manufactured composite.

questions.question: Choose one everyday product (e.g., a glass jar, a wooden ladder or a metal frying pan) and sketch a design showing how you could repurpose it for a new use. Label the sketch to explain which material properties make it suitable for its new purpose.
Which statement best describes the scientific property called elasticity?

answers.content: A material that keeps its new shape after being stretched or squashed.
answers.explanation: If the material does not return to its original shape it is plastic, not elastic.

answers.content: A material that is able to conduct electricity.
answers.explanation: Conductivity is a different property.

answers.content: A material that returns to its original shape after a deforming force is removed.
answers.explanation: Elastic materials ‘bounce back’ to their original shape when the force is taken away.

answers.content: A material that breaks easily under pressure.
answers.explanation: Brittleness is the tendency to break, not elasticity.

questions.question: In the bouncing-ball investigation, why must all balls be dropped from the same height onto the same surface?

answers.content: To make the video easier to record in slow motion.
answers.explanation: Recording quality is not the main scientific reason.

answers.content: To save time while conducting the investigation.
answers.explanation: Time saving is not the goal of a fair test.

answers.content: To keep the test fair so that only the elasticity of the balls affects how high they bounce.
answers.explanation: Using identical conditions controls variables other than elasticity.

answers.content: Because rulers only measure one metre accurately in one place.
answers.explanation: Measurement accuracy does not depend on location.

questions.question: Name TWO everyday activities from the lesson that rely on elasticity and briefly state why elasticity is important for each activity.

answers.content: Sample answer: (1) Jumping on a trampoline – the elastic mat stretches and recoils to lift the jumper back up. (2) Bungee jumping – the elastic cord stretches to slow the jumper safely and then recoils.
answers.explanation: Any two of the following with correct reasons earn full marks: playing elastics, bouncing on a trampoline, bungee jumping, firing a slingshot.

questions.question: Based on their typical materials, which ball from the list below would you predict to have the HIGHEST elasticity (highest bounce)?

answers.explanation: The layered leather and cork make it less bouncy.
Golf balls are hard and designed for distance, not maximum bounce on the spot.
Rubber is highly elastic, so a hand ball usually bounces higher than the others.
A ping-pong ball is light and does not bounce as high as a solid rubber ball from the same height.

questions.question: What happens to a tennis ball when it hits the ground and bounces back up?

answers.content: It keeps its shape while energy magically pushes it upward.
answers.explanation: The ball actually squashes and then reforms.

answers.content: It briefly flattens, then its elastic rubber core expands back, pushing on the ground and sending the ball upward.
answers.explanation: Compression followed by elastic recovery causes the bounce.

answers.content: Air escapes from the ball, making it lighter so it rises.
answers.explanation: The internal pressure stays inside the ball during a normal bounce.

answers.content: The felt cover grips the floor and creates spin instead of bounce.
answers.explanation: Spin can occur, but the main bounce comes from elasticity of the core.

questions.question: Explain how understanding the properties of materials helps designers choose the best material for making a particular sports ball.

answers.content: Sample answer: Designers test properties such as elasticity, hardness and weight. Knowing, for example, that rubber is elastic tells them it will give basketballs good bounce, while a harder material like cork and leather makes a cricket ball travel fast without too much bounce. Matching material properties to how the ball needs to perform leads to better, safer equipment.
answers.explanation: Response should mention matching specific material properties (e.g. elasticity) to the required performance of the sports ball.
